awd_titl_txt: Support for 2018 International Union of Crystallography High Pressure Workshop: Honolulu, HI, July 29 - August 2, 2018
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides financial support for participation of 10 early career (graduate student, postdoc or tenure-track faculty) at the 2018 Workshop of the International Union of Crystallography (IUCr) Commission on High Pressure, which will be held in Honolulu Hawaii, from July 29, until August 2, 2018 at the Ala Moana Hotel. 3.5 days of regular conference program will be preceded with a one full-day student/postdoc training event on analysis of single crystal X-ray diffraction data at high pressure.

Extreme-conditions science is a vibrant, multidisciplinary field that characterizes unique states of matter, simulates processes that take place in inaccessible environments such as planetary interiors, and synthesizes new materials with properties that have compelling technological applications. Understanding of the effect of pressure on minerals and earth forming materials is central to geophysics, mineral physics and planetary science. The interiors of all planetary bodies are built of minerals that exist under high pressure and temperature conditions. Meteorite ejection and impact phenomena involve generation of dynamic shock pressure. Understanding how pressure affects the structure, properties and behavior of minerals enables understanding of global phenomena such as earthquakes, volcanism, plate tectonics, etc. Proper education of the new generation of earth scientists who will study and model properties and processes of planetary interiors is an issue of great importance for the future of geosciences, and represents a significant challenge. The workshop will emphasize training of young scientists in basic principles of single crystal sample preparation, data collecting and analysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant funded 12 travel awards given to US-institution-based young scientists, to allow them to attend the Workshop of International Union of Crystallography Commission on High Pressure (IUCr HP), entitled "E3: Extreme materials, extreme phenomena, extreme environments".  The Workshop was held on July 29-August 2, 2018 at the Ala Moana Hotel in Honolulu, HI. 

High-pressure crystallography plays a central role in mineral physics. The topics covered at the 2018 IUCr HP workshop were of great importance to the new generation of geophysics and mineral physics scientists. New, groundbreaking experimental techniques, as well as advanced computational approaches used to study structure, properties and transformations of minerals in Earth and planetary interiors, as well as the theoretical background necessary to understand these phenomena was covered. Additional multidisciplinary topics such as synthetic chemistry aspects, or behavior of biomolecules and microorganisms at high pressure created a unique blend of subjects that equipped the participants with a very broad overview and understanding of high-pressure science.

The regular IUCr HP Workshop was proceeded by one full day data analysis training event focused single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiments at high pressure. This training event was held at the University of Hawaii campus was offered free of charge to the conference attendees. 52 attendees participated in the training event. The training event included lecture presentations by leading international experts and COMPRES facility beamline scientists as well as practical hands-on sessions in computer labs, where the attendees were encouraged to bring their own laptops and install the software. Demo data from both a synchrotron beamline and home-lab X-ray source instruments was provided to the training event participants for practice.

Special session "Women under pressure" offered opportunities to discuss special challenges and opportunities that female scientists face on their career paths in research in academia, at government labs and in private sector.
